body:
Here's the image I'm trying to verify:

![broken](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/299979/13469525/961aa10c-e05c-11e5-8e0a-333175820e04.png)

rename.from: Image.verify raises struct.error (instead of IOError) on Pillow 3.1.1
rename.to: Image.verify raises struct.error (instead of... IndexError?) on Pillow 3.1.1

body: Verified that this test (for IndexError) works on 2.3.0, the last version I was testing with. I'll check a few more versions to try to narrow it down.

rename.from: Image.verify raises struct.error (instead of... IndexError?) on Pillow 3.1.1
rename.to: Image.verify raises struct.error (instead of... IndexError) on Pillow 3.1.1

rename.from: Image.verify raises struct.error (instead of... IndexError) on Pillow 3.1.1
rename.to: Image.verify raises struct.error (instead of... IndexError) on Pillow > 2.7.0

rename.from: Image.verify raises struct.error (instead of... IndexError) on Pillow > 2.7.0
rename.to: Image.verify raises struct.error (instead of IndexError) on Pillow > 2.7.0

body: The underlying implementation of the binary functions changed to `struct.unpack` at about 2.7 and every time that we throw a `struct.error` it's because of that change.
That change was in PR #1121, which was released in 2.8.0.

issue.title: Add handling of struct.error during Image.verify
issue.body: See python-pillow/Pillow#1755. Pillow now throws struct.error in certain situations where we expect something else (specifically IndexError). Though that may or may not be the proper behavior, there are at least 3 versions of Pillow out with this behavior; we should handle it.

body: Given that you've created a PR in another project to act on this, are you right for this issue to be closed?

I mean... I need to support both in any case, so I don't care. The question is more what you feel is a more appropriate error as far as I'm concerned. :-) I'm guessing struct.error might make more sense? But OTOH I personally wouldn't have known that was a struct.error if you hadn't told me, which makes the error message pretty opaque.

But yeah, I personally don't need anything from you on this.
We've treated this as an error for opening files, it makes sense to do it for verify. (though, verify is a very inconsistently supported function, currently it's only available for pngs)

issue.title: Catch struct.errors when verifying png files
